body:

          config="{ChainID: 11 Homestead: 0 DAO: <nil> DAOSupport: false EIP150: <nil>
 EIP155: 0 EIP158: 0 Byzantium: 0 Constantinople: <nil> Petersburg: <nil>
 Istanbul: <nil> Engine: unknown}"

My results, 
```
1.9.1: 76942
e76047e9f5499b58064bddde514dd3119a090adf: 76942
1.9.2: 76942

```
using this command line: 
```
geth --dev js --dev.period 1 test.js 
```
with `test.js`:
```javascript

loadScript('o_o.js')
inner = Inner_new()
outer = Outer_new()
setTimeout(function(){

	outer.setImplementation(inner.address, {from:eth.accounts[0]})
	tmp = web3.eth.contract(Inner_contract.abi).at(outer.address)
	tmp.value()
	tx = tmp.set(100, {from:eth.accounts[0], gas:100000})
	tmp.value()
        setTimeout(function(){
		trace = debug.traceTransaction(tx)
		console.log(trace.structLogs[47])
	        console.log(trace.structLogs[47].gasCost)
	}, 2000)

}, 5000)

```
and `o_o.js` same as yours, except I replaced the `gas` in the transactions to (they were 200+M) with `0x5b8d80`). 
So, I can't repro the faults .. However, I did run into some odd things when I didn't wait for transactions to be mined properly, which may explain some quirky behaviour, hence why I added the timeouts.

I confirm that it works in 'dev' network, which has the following configuration.

```
INFO [10-14|19:08:07.421] Initialised chain configuration          config="{Chai
nID: 1337 Homestead: 0 DAO: <nil> DAOSupport: false EIP150: 0 EIP155: 0 EIP158: 
0 Byzantium: 0 Constantinople: 0 Petersburg: 0 Istanbul: <nil> Engine: clique}"
```
Ok, I can repro it now, if I don't use `--dev`

The problem goes away if you define `"eip150Block": 0`. The problem is that we refactored the instructions, and that the instruction set for `EIP 158 a.k.a Spurious Dragon` _includes_ instruction set from `EIP 150 a.k.a Tangerine Whistle`. So you still have all Eip 150 instructions, like DELEGATECALL. However, the gas schedule becomes a bit mishmash - and the check if we should use the `63/64ths` rule (`gas.go`) checks if 150 is enabled -- which it isn't. So it doesn't apply the rule, and things become a bit strange.

So you're using a configuration which is not supported -- geth is not built to be able to handle hardforks in arbitrary order. You can select them up to a point, but if you omit one you can't really enable the next one. 

What we should do is enforce/check this during startup or initialization, as it can be very difficult to figure this out once it has happened.
holiman, you're correct on `eip150` being the culprit. With that set to `0`, it works as expected. I agree with what you suggest as well.
